727790f-a.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 63rd Avenue
727790f-a.text:
Queens Boulevard (left, electric poles thereon), between Sixty-
third Ave. and 62nd Drive, showing the M. Covert house. See other
views for more data. This is a group of four, showing the front, side,
and rear of the house.
February 1924.
Views 1, 3 and 4.
View 2: August 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

725525f-b.title: Queens: 63rd Avenue - Queens Boulevard
725525f-b.text:
Sixty-third Ave. (sidewalk thereon), at the S.W. corner of
Queens Boulevard (automobiles thereon), showing the original
Presbyterian Paraonage later known as the Thompson house. It was
subsequently purchased by the Rego Construction Company and became
a part of the Rego Park. This house was used by the Company as a
sales office. This is a set of two views.
May 1926.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

725525f-a.title: Queens: 63rd Avenue - Queens Boulevard

727769f-a.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 63rd Avenue
727769f-a.text:
9ueens Boulevard (left, trolley line thereon), east from Sixty-
third Ave. (Marion Ave.). Note the proposed widening of Queens
Boulevard (formerly Hoffman Boulevard.)
May 1926.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

727789f-b.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 62nd Drive
727789f-b.text:
9ueens Boulevard, north side, at 62nd Drive, showing four
views of the Horst (whitehhouse of 1896. Beyond it is a pumping
station for this area. At the left is seen in view three, the
rear of the Covert house. In the center background is the Thompson
house and barn. Note also the filling in and widening in views
3 annd 4.
Anril 1923
View 2:  Fehruary 8, 1924
View 3:  February 1924
View 4;  March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

727766f-d.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 63rd Avenue
727766f-d.text:
Queens Boulevard (formerly 287 Eoffman Boulevard), between
Sixty-third Ave. (right) and 62nd Drive (left). This house was
formerly on the north side of the old Oueens Boulevard Street line.
When the street was widened it stood in the center thereof and because
of this was either demolished or burned down. This is a set of four
views. The occupants or owners were: M. Covert 1852-1860, Mrs. H. R.
Covert 1873, Frost T. Covert Sr. 1873, and Frost T. Covert Jr.
April 1922.
Views 2 and 3: April 1923.
View 4: February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

727767f-b.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 63rd Avenue
727767f-b.text:
Wueens Boulevard, west from 63rd Avenue. View 1 shows an old
house, said to have been a parsonage,on the south side of the Boule-
vard. It is No. 9272 Cueens Boulevard. To tbue right are the old
Thompson barns in rear of the Thompson farmhouse which later became
the Rego Park real estate office.
View 2 shows a more extensive view of the Boulevard. The house
on the left is No. 9272, the one seewin view 1. The white house
in the background is the pre-Revolutionary Thompson House. On the
right is a pumping station. Cueens Boulevard is being widened; the
buildings on the left mark the new building line and the new width
of the thoroughfare.
View 1: February, 1924
View 2: May, 19A6
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

727768f-c.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 63rd Avenue
727768f-c.text:
Queens Boulevard (formerly 287 Hoffman Boulevardl, between
Sixty-third Ave. (right) and Sixty-second Drive (left). This
house was formerly on the north side of the Old Queens Boulevard
Street line. When the Boulevard was widened it stood in the
center thereof, and because of this was either demolished or
burned. This is a set of four views showing the M. Covert house.
See other views for more data.
1922
Views 2 and 3:Feb. 1924.
View 41 Aug. 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

727791f-c.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - 63rd Avenue
727791f-c.text:
Queens Boulevard, north side, between Sixty-third Averue
(foreground not shown) and 82nd Drive (background, not shown).
At the right, beyornd the signboards is the M. Covert house of
1852-1860. Mrs. H. Covert was the owner in 1873. In the back-
oround, center, faintly distinguishable, is the home of
Mrs. Howard. View No. 2 shows the Covert house oractically de-
molished. The new street line for Queens Boulevard will probably
extend to a point beyond the house. Views 3 and 4 show a rear
of the house which is hidden bv an outhouse.
April 1923.
View 2: March 1925.
Views 334: February 8, 1924.
'gene L. Armbruster Collection
